awd_titl_txt: Standard Grant: Genetic Counselors and the Ethics of Translating Genomic Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposed research will explore how genetic counselors are bridging the world of science and the clinic in their role of providing information to the public on genetic science.  By asking what genetic counselors consider to be the nuances and goals of their professional responsibilities, this proposed study will identify the tensions of genetic counseling and ethical aspects of translating genetic science to users. Findings of this proposed study will be of interest to researchers, policymakers, genetic counselors, medical community, and the general public. It will further scientific and public understandings of what counts as legitimate expertise and knowledge. It will identify processes to improve the public's uptake of science. In addition, it will contribute to understanding how to ground abstract bioethical principles in everyday encounters and to prepare professionals to respond to the ethical dilemmas of translating genetic knowledge and technologies.

Utilizing a multi-sited qualitative research approach, this proposed research draws on data from in-depth interviews, observations, and textual documents. It will bridge and blend existing science studies scholarship on scientists' research practices in the lab with analysis of practitioners' everyday decision-making in the clinic. In so doing, the proposed study uses concepts of ethical work, boundary making, and knowledge production to exam medical care in the clinic. By focusing on genetic counselors whose specific role is to provide information in order to facilitate individual decisions and expectations, this proposed study will analyze genetic counselors' assessment of their role in translating genetic knowledge and its consequences.  It will develop a framework through which to analyze other meso-level professions engaged in translational medicine.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined the perspectives and professional roles of a key translator of new genomic technologies, master's-trained genetic counselors, across an array of arenas -- from prenatal cancer and pediatrics to fields that are increasingly using and producing genetic knowledge, such as cardiology, neurology, infertility, and the biotechnology industry. By centering the genetic counseling profession's standpoint, this project investigated the relatively unexplored pathways of genomic science, and the various ethical and professional quandaries that are negotiated and produced as genetic knowledge gets translated in clinical spaces.

Findings from this study reveal that genetic counselors are optimistic about developments in genomic science and medicine.  At the same time, their on-the-ground experiences with patients and physicians present some concerns for the counseling profession about how genetic science is being integrated into health care settings and medical decision-making. As experts on both the science of genetics and the psycho-social dimensions of how individuals receive and act upon genetic information, counselors view their profession as uniquely situated to provide important expert feedback and guidance in clinical settings. As a health professional that engages multiple stakeholders, genetic counselors' perspectives are also crucial to bioethical considerations and health policymaking. Counselors view themselves as key genetic translators and advocates of informed decision-making, particularly in the context of recent advances and expansions of genomic science where testing results often produce complex and ambiguous information that can be misinterpreted by the public, patients, and physicians. This project on genetic counselors serves as an important case study to understand how health care workers and scientists address complexity in medicine and educate others about how uncertainty surrounds health care decision-making.  Results from this study point to the need for improved health literacy, and particularly genetic literacy, for genomic knowledge to be widely impactful, equitable, and beneficial.

Overall, this project contributes to scientific, medical, and public understandings of contemporary biomedical knowledge production and its translation from the lab to the clinic. The results of this research have been disseminated through presentations in various sociological and science and technology studies settings, as well as to audiences of bioethicists, clinicians, and genetic counselors.
